questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the physician because of a swelling at the back of his left knee that he first noticed 2 months ago. The swelling is not painful, but he occasionally experiences pain at the back of his knee when he is standing for prolonged periods. He also reports mild stiffness of the knee when he wakes up in the morning that disappears after a few minutes of waking up and moving about. Examination shows no local calf tenderness, but forced dorsiflexion of the foot aggravates his knee pain. There is a 3-cm, mildly tender, fixed mass at the medial side of the left popliteal fossa. The mass is more prominent on extension and disappears upon flexion of the left knee. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Mutation of coagulation factor V gene

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Consumption of a purine-rich diet (large amounts of animal protein) may predispose to hyperuricemia and flares in patients with gout. Although gouty arthritis can present with tender mass lesions and knee pain, this patient's presentation with a swelling of the popliteal fossa is most consistent with a Baker cyst, which is unrelated to diet.

B) INCORRECT:

Varicose veins can predispose to thrombophlebitis, which would manifest with a tender cord-like mass over the popliteal fossa. This patient's nontender mass that varies in size with flexion and extension is more consistent with a Baker cyst, which is not associated with varicose veins.

C) INCORRECT:

Defects in the synthesis of collagen can cause Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS). This syndrome increases the risk of vascular aneurysms. Although a large popliteal aneurysm would also manifest as a mass in the popliteal fossa, an aneurysm would classically be pulsatile on examination. This patient has a nonpulsatile popliteal cyst and lacks the classical signs of EDS (joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, etc.).
Image Description:

The skin of the elbow is hyperelastic (cutis hyperelastica) due to impaired collagen synthesis.

This, along with joint hypermobility, is a characteristic feature of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

A factor V Leiden mutation would increase the risk of deep venous thrombosis (DVT). Although DVT can present similarly to Baker cysts (swelling and pain with aggravation on dorsal flexion of the foot or after long periods of standing), this patient's local swelling in the popliteal fossa and the characteristic pain in the back of the knee is more suggestive of a popliteal cyst than DVT. Moreover, DVT would show warm skin and erythema which are not present in this patient.

An enlarged popliteal cyst may increase the risk of deep venous thrombosis by compression. Cyst rupture and subsequent leakage of synovial fluid caudally into the lower leg muscles may appear similar to a DVT.
Image Description:

There is diffuse edema and erythema of the right leg and foot. The diameter of the right calf is visibly greater than that of the left.

These features are typical of DVT. Clinical history and investigations (e.g., Doppler ultrasonography, D-dimer levels) help distinguish between DVT and cellulitis, which also manifests with a painful, warm, erythematous, and edematous leg.

E) INCORRECT:

A history of lipomatosis may predispose to popliteal lipoma, which would present as a nontender, movable mass that would not vary with flexion or extension. This patient presents with a popliteal cyst, which is unrelated to a history of lipomatosis.
Image Description:

There is a solitary soft subcutaneous nodule under normal-appearing skin. If the nodule is pushed by gently sliding a finger over the edge, the lipoma tends to slip away from the examining finger (slippage/slip sign).

F) INCORRECT:

Antibodies to double-stranded DNA are seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which can affect the joints. Unlike rheumatoid arthritis (RA), SLE is not commonly associated with Baker cysts, which this patient has. RA is associated with rheumatoid factor, not with double-stranded DNA antibodies.

G) CORRECT:

A strong predisposing factor for the formation of Baker cysts is a history of knee trauma (present in up to a third of patients with popliteal cysts). Trauma and the associated inflammation of the synovium can stimulate the production of synovial fluid, which subsequently leads to the development of a cyst. Other risk factors for Baker cysts include inflammatory or degenerative joint diseases of the knee, especially rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis.
Image Description:

Dorsomedial view of the knee with swelling in the popliteal fossa indicating popliteal cyst (arrow).
questions.hint: This patient has a medial popliteal mass that disappears upon flexion of the knee (when the joint space is widened) that is suggestive of a popliteal (Baker) cyst. During extension of the knee, the mass increases in size as the joint space is narrowed and excess synovial fluid is sequestered in the popliteal space.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother after she noticed a bulge behind his right knee while they were playing together 2 days ago. She says that he is otherwise well and extremely active. The patient has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Growth and development are appropriate for age. Vaccinations are up-to-date. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination of the right knee, active and passive range of motion is full without crepitus. A soft nontender swelling is present in the right popliteal region; the swelling becomes more prominent with knee extension. There is no warmth or erythema of the skin overlying the bulge, and there is no evidence of swelling, effusion, or point tenderness elsewhere on the right knee. The remainder of the physical examination, including examination of the left knee, shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography of the right knee shows a 3.5 x 2 x 3 cm, fluid-filled sac between the semimembranosus muscle and the medial head of the gastrocnemius muscle. Ultrasonography of the left knee shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Application of a compression knee sleeve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the knee may be considered for further evaluation of patients with popliteal cysts caused by degenerative disease of the knee (e.g., osteoarthritis). This child has an asymptomatic popliteal cyst with no features that suggest degenerative disease (e.g., pain, swelling, decreased range of motion).

B) CORRECT:

Reassurance and observation alone are recommended for asymptomatic popliteal cysts. Primary popliteal cysts generally have a self-limiting course and resolve spontaneously within 1–2 years. Patients who have an uncertain diagnosis, symptomatic popliteal cysts, or in whom a secondary cause of popliteal cysts is suspected may require further workup (e.g., x-ray, MRI of the knee). Surgical excision may be considered for primary popliteal cysts that are symptomatic (e.g., pain, limited range of motion) or fail to resolve spontaneously.

For symptomatic secondary popliteal cysts, the initial treatment consists of treating the underlying disease, and arthrocentesis followed by intraarticular glucocorticoid injection. If symptoms persist, direct ultrasound-guided aspiration of the cyst and glucocorticoid injection directly into the cyst can be attempted before considering arthroscopic excision.
Image Description:

Dorsomedial view of the knee with swelling in the popliteal fossa indicating popliteal cyst (arrow).

C) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopic resection of a popliteal cyst may be considered in symptomatic patients with an associated history of a traumatic or degenerative knee condition (e.g., meniscal lesion, rheumatoid arthritis). This child most likely has an asymptomatic primary popliteal cyst and does not have a history of intraarticular pathology. Moreover, arthroscopic surgery is not the first-line intervention in children because there is a risk of growth plate damage during the procedure.

D) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis followed by intraarticular glucocorticoid injection might be required for symptomatic secondary popliteal cysts, not for asymptomatic primary popliteal cysts. Arthrocentesis also is required for the evaluation of suspected septic arthritis or hemarthrosis. However, this patient is asymptomatic and has no characteristic features of septic arthritis (e.g., fever, joint pain, decreased range of motion) or hemarthrosis (e.g., joint pain, decreased range of motion, history of trauma, history of a bleeding disorder).

E) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound-guided needle aspiration of the swelling followed by glucocorticoid injection into the swelling might be required for symptomatic secondary popliteal cysts, not for asymptomatic primary popliteal cysts.

F) INCORRECT:

A compression knee sleeve may be considered for symptom relief in patients with degenerative disease of the knee (e.g., osteoarthritis), which is commonly associated with the development of popliteal cysts in adult patients. This child has an asymptomatic popliteal cyst and no history or symptoms of intraarticular pathology (e.g., pain, swelling, decreased range of motion). A compression knee sleeve has not been shown to effectively treat popliteal cysts.
questions.hint: An asymptomatic fluid-filled sac between the semimembranosus and gastrocnemius muscles suggests a popliteal cyst. Unlike popliteal cysts in adults, which are often due to an intraarticular pathology (e.g., osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, meniscal lesions) and communicate with the joint space, popliteal cysts in children are usually idiopathic (“primary popliteal cysts”), not associated with an underlying condition, and do not communicate with the joint space.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old woman with bilateral knee osteoarthritis presents with left-knee pain and swelling that make it difficult for her to fully flex the knee. She denies any recent trauma, fevers, or chills. Rest, ice, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications, and a glucocorticoid injection into the knee joint 3 months ago have not relieved her symptoms.
Examination of the left knee reveals minimal tenderness along the joint lines but fullness and tenderness in the posterior aspect of the knee, most prominent with knee extension. The patient has full extension but limited flexion at the knee. There is crepitus and a small effusion without warmth or erythema, as well as 1+ edema at the left shin. No cords are palpable.
A lower-extremity Doppler ultrasound shows no evidence of deep-vein thrombosis but reveals a 4-cm x 3-cm fluid collection at the posterior aspect of the knee.
What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

choices.text: Ultrasound-guided cyst aspiration and glucocorticoid injection
Ultrasound-guided cyst aspiration without glucocorticoid injection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral glucocorticoids are unlikely to be effective in the management of a popliteal cyst that has arisen because of osteoarthritis. They may be effective in reducing the size of a popliteal cyst in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis, however.

B) CORRECT:

Popliteal (Baker) cysts form at the medial and distal aspect of the posterior knee after enlargement of the gastrocnemius-semimembranosus bursa, which communicates with the knee-joint space in adults. Popliteal cysts result from intra-articular knee pathology, most often osteoarthritis (OA) but also occasionally meniscal tears or inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis. These cysts accumulate fluid through a one-way valve mechanism and can become swollen and painful.

Management of a symptomatic popliteal cyst should focus on the underlying joint pathology that is causing the fluid collection. When conservative measures fail (including glucocorticoid injection into the knee joint), the next step is ultrasound-guided aspiration of the cyst with glucocorticoid injection into either the knee joint or the cyst itself. Cyst aspiration and injection should be performed only by experienced providers using imaging guidance because blind attempts can injure the neurovascular structures.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a symptomatic popliteal cyst that has arisen because of osteoarthritis and has not responded to conservative measures (including glucocorticoid injection into the knee joint) is ultrasound-guided cyst aspiration and glucocorticoid injection.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspiration of the cyst alone can relieve pressure transiently, but recurrence is common.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection of a popliteal cyst is rarely necessary but can be considered in cases of severe symptoms refractory to injections into the cyst or the knee joint.

E) INCORRECT:

Quadriceps-strengthening exercises are often used to treat knee osteoarthritis; however, hamstring strengthening is unlikely to help with pain from a popliteal cyst, especially if knee flexion induces pain.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a bulge behind his right knee. The patient is otherwise well and extremely active. Growth and development are appropriate for age. On examination of the right knee, active and passive range of motion is full without crepitus. A soft nontender swelling is present in the right popliteal region; the swelling becomes more prominent with knee extension. Ultrasonography of the right knee shows a 3.5 x 2 x 3 cm, fluid-filled sac between the semimembranosus muscle and the medial head of the gastrocnemius muscle. choices.text: Application of a compression knee sleeve

A) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the knee may be considered for further evaluation of patients with popliteal cysts caused by degenerative disease of the knee (e.g., osteoarthritis). This child has an asymptomatic popliteal cyst with no features that suggest degenerative disease (e.g., pain, swelling, decreased range of motion).

Reassurance and observation alone are recommended for asymptomatic popliteal cysts. Primary popliteal cysts generally have a self-limiting course and resolve spontaneously within 1–2 years. Patients who have an uncertain diagnosis, symptomatic popliteal cysts, or in whom a secondary cause of popliteal cysts is suspected may require further workup (e.g., x-ray, MRI of the knee). Surgical excision may be considered for primary popliteal cysts that are symptomatic (e.g., pain, limited range of motion) or fail to resolve spontaneously.

For symptomatic secondary popliteal cysts, the initial treatment consists of treating the underlying disease, and arthrocentesis followed by intraarticular glucocorticoid injection. If symptoms persist, direct ultrasound-guided aspiration of the cyst and glucocorticoid injection directly into the cyst can be attempted before considering arthroscopic excision.
Image Description:

Dorsomedial view of the knee with swelling in the popliteal fossa indicating popliteal cyst (arrow).

C) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopic resection of a popliteal cyst may be considered in symptomatic patients with an associated history of a traumatic or degenerative knee condition (e.g., meniscal lesion, rheumatoid arthritis). This child most likely has an asymptomatic primary popliteal cyst and does not have a history of intraarticular pathology. Moreover, arthroscopic surgery is not the first-line intervention in children because there is a risk of growth plate damage during the procedure.

D) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis followed by intraarticular glucocorticoid injection might be required for symptomatic secondary popliteal cysts, not for asymptomatic primary popliteal cysts. Arthrocentesis also is required for the evaluation of suspected septic arthritis or hemarthrosis. However, this patient is asymptomatic and has no characteristic features of septic arthritis (e.g., fever, joint pain, decreased range of motion) or hemarthrosis (e.g., joint pain, decreased range of motion, history of trauma, history of a bleeding disorder).

A compression knee sleeve may be considered for symptom relief in patients with degenerative disease of the knee (e.g., osteoarthritis), which is commonly associated with the development of popliteal cysts in adult patients. This child has an asymptomatic popliteal cyst and no history or symptoms of intraarticular pathology (e.g., pain, swelling, decreased range of motion). A compression knee sleeve has not been shown to effectively treat popliteal cysts.

Unlike popliteal cysts in adults, which are often due to an intraarticular pathology (e.g., osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, meniscal lesions) and communicate with the joint space, popliteal cysts in children are usually idiopathic (“primary popliteal cysts”), not associated with an underlying condition, and do not communicate with the joint space.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to your clinic because of a bulge behind his right knee. He is otherwise well and very active. His growth and development are appropriate for his age. On examination, the right knee has full active and passive range of motion without crepitus. There is a soft, nontender swelling in the right popliteal region that becomes more prominent with knee extension. Ultrasonography of the right knee reveals a 3.5 x 2 x 3 cm fluid-filled sac between the semimembranosus muscle and the medial head of the gastrocnemius muscle. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Application of a compression knee sleeve.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A compression knee sleeve may be considered for symptom relief in patients with degenerative disease of the knee (e.g., osteoarthritis), which is commonly associated with the development of popliteal cysts in adult patients. This child has an asymptomatic popliteal cyst and no history or symptoms of intraarticular pathology (e.g., pain, swelling, decreased range of motion). A compression knee sleeve has not been shown to effectively treat popliteal cysts.

B) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis followed by intraarticular glucocorticoid injection might be required for symptomatic secondary popliteal cysts, not for asymptomatic primary popliteal cysts. Arthrocentesis also is required for the evaluation of suspected septic arthritis or hemarthrosis. However, this patient is asymptomatic and has no characteristic features of septic arthritis (e.g., fever, joint pain, decreased range of motion) or hemarthrosis (e.g., joint pain, decreased range of motion, history of trauma, history of a bleeding disorder).

C) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the knee may be considered for further evaluation of patients with popliteal cysts caused by degenerative disease of the knee (e.g., osteoarthritis). This child has an asymptomatic popliteal cyst with no features that suggest degenerative disease (e.g., pain, swelling, decreased range of motion).

D) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopic resection of a popliteal cyst may be considered in symptomatic patients with an associated history of a traumatic or degenerative knee condition (e.g., meniscal lesion, rheumatoid arthritis). This child most likely has an asymptomatic primary popliteal cyst and does not have a history of intraarticular pathology. Moreover, arthroscopic surgery is not the first-line intervention in children because there is a risk of growth plate damage during the procedure.

E) CORRECT:

Reassurance and observation alone are recommended for asymptomatic popliteal cysts. Primary popliteal cysts generally have a self-limiting course and resolve spontaneously within 1–2 years. Patients who have an uncertain diagnosis, symptomatic popliteal cysts, or in whom a secondary cause of popliteal cysts is suspected may require further workup (e.g., x-ray, MRI of the knee). Surgical excision may be considered for primary popliteal cysts that are symptomatic (e.g., pain, limited range of motion) or fail to resolve spontaneously.

For symptomatic secondary popliteal cysts, the initial treatment consists of treating the underlying disease, and arthrocentesis followed by intraarticular glucocorticoid injection. If symptoms persist, direct ultrasound-guided aspiration of the cyst and glucocorticoid injection directly into the cyst can be attempted before considering arthroscopic excision.

Key learning point: Asymptomatic popliteal (Baker) cysts in children are typically self-limited and should be managed with observation and reassurance rather than intervention.
Image Description:

Dorsomedial view of the knee with swelling in the popliteal fossa indicating popliteal cyst (arrow).
questions.hint: An asymptomatic fluid-filled sac between the semimembranosus and gastrocnemius muscles suggests a popliteal cyst. Unlike popliteal cysts in adults, which are often due to an intraarticular pathology (e.g., osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, meniscal lesions) and communicate with the joint space, popliteal cysts in children are usually idiopathic (“primary popliteal cysts”), not associated with an underlying condition, and do not communicate with the joint space.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a 4-day history of posterior knee pain and swelling. She reports that the pain is worse with walking and improves with rest. Physical examination shows a palpable mass in the popliteal fossa and mild calf swelling and tenderness. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Ultrasound of the posterior knee and calf
CT angiography of the lower extremity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation suggests a popliteal cyst. Arthrocentesis is not indicated for diagnosing popliteal cysts because it carries unnecessary risks and does not rule out deep vein thrombosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs may show a soft tissue mass but cannot differentiate between various causes of posterior knee swelling. This modality do not help rule out deep vein thrombosis, which is essential given this patient's posterior knee and calf symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI can identify underlying joint pathology and confirm a popliteal cyst diagnosis. However, it cannot rule out deep vein thrombosis and is more appropriate for outpatient evaluation of underlying joint conditions.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Ultrasound is the most appropriate initial study because it can confirm a popliteal cyst and simultaneously rule out deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Large or ruptured popliteal cysts can cause calf swelling and mimic DVT (pseudothrombophlebitis syndrome), making exclusion of DVT critical in an emergency.

E) INCORRECT:

While CT angiography may identify vascular pathology, this patient's clinical presentation suggests a popliteal cyst rather than arterial causes, and CT angiography does not rule out venous thrombosis.
